title: 104_s270
content: The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" allows for the removal of alien terrorists under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" defines key terms such as 'alien terrorist', 'classified information', 'national security', 'special court', and 'special removal hearing'. The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" defines key terms related to national security, special court, and special removal hearing. The Attorney General must certify to the special court for the provisions of this section to apply. The provisions of the Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995 apply when the Attorney General certifies to the special court that an alien terrorist is in the US and deportation proceedings would risk national security by disclosing classified information. The Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995 applies when an alien terrorist is physically present in the US, and deportation proceedings would risk national security by disclosing classified information. A special court with up to seven designated judges from different judicial districts hears and decides cases under this section. The Chief Justice of the United States designates up to seven judges from different judicial districts to hear cases under the Alien Terrorist Removal Act. The same judges may be designated as those under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. The Chief Justice may designate judges for cases under the Alien Terrorist Removal Act and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. A single judge of the special court considers applications in camera and ex parte if there is probable cause to believe in alien involvement. A single judge of the special court considers applications in camera and ex parte if there is probable cause to believe that the alien has been correctly identified and a deportation proceeding would pose a risk to national security by disclosing classified information. The special removal hearing is authorized by a showing of probable cause, where the alien's physical presence poses an immediate threat of death or serious bodily harm, and a deportation proceeding would risk disclosing classified information. The special removal hearing, based on probable cause, is open to the public and allows the alien to be present with legal representation provided if needed. The alien has the right to be present at the special removal hearing, be represented by counsel, introduce evidence, and cross-examine witnesses. If unable to afford counsel, one will be assigned. The alien in a special removal hearing has the right to introduce evidence, cross-examine witnesses, and request a subpoena for witness presence. The judge can allow the introduction of evidence in camera if public disclosure poses a national security risk. The judge can authorize the introduction of evidence in camera if public disclosure poses a national security risk. The judge may substitute evidence with a statement admitting relevant facts or a summary to the alien. The judge may substitute evidence with a statement admitting relevant facts or a summary to the alien, or inform the alien if disclosure poses a risk of harm. The judge can substitute evidence with a statement or summary for the alien if disclosure may pose a risk of harm. If the judge determines that substituted evidence will provide the alien with the same defense ability or if disclosure of the substituted evidence would pose a risk of harm, deportation may be determined under this section. If evidence in paragraph (5)(A) poses a risk of death or serious harm, deportation may be determined under this section. The judge must require deportation if the Attorney General proves by clear and convincing evidence that the alien is subject to deportation. If the determination in subsection (e)(6)(A) or (e)(6)(B) has been made, the judge shall require deportation if the Attorney General proves by clear and convincing evidence that the alien is subject to deportation. If the determination in subsection (e)(6)(B) has been made, the judge shall require deportation if the Attorney General proves, by clear, convincing, and unequivocal evidence, that the alien is subject to deportation as described in section 241(a)(4)(B). The alien may appeal this determination to the court of appeals for the Federal Circuit within twenty days. The alien may appeal a determination under subsection (f) to the court of appeals for the Federal Circuit within twenty days. The Attorney General may also appeal a determination under subsection (d), (e), or (f) to the court of appeals for the Federal Circuit within twenty days. The Attorney General may appeal a determination under subsections (d), (e), or (f) to the court of appeals for the Federal Circuit within twenty days by filing a notice of appeal. Upon request, the entire record of the proceeding shall be transmitted to the court of appeals under seal for consideration in camera and ex parte.
